title-group.article-title: Pre-ignition and ‘super-knock’ in turbo-charged spark-ignition engines

fn.p: Now at Saudi-Aramco, Dhahran, Saudi Arabia

author-notes.corresp: Derek Bradley, Shell Technology Centre, Chester CH1 3SH Email: D.Bradley@leeds.ac.uk

abstract.p: Earlier studies of pre-ignitions at hot surfaces are first reviewed. The concept of a critical radius of a hot pocket of gas, closely related to the laminar flame thickness, that is necessary to initiate a propagating flame, has been used successfully to predict relative tendencies of different fuel–air mixtures to pre-ignite. As the mixture is compressed, the thickness of potential laminar flames decreases, and when this becomes of the order of the thermal sheath thickness at the hottest surface, pre-ignition can occur there, creating a propagating flame. Measured engine pre-ignition ratings are shown to correlate well with laminar flame thicknesses. Predictions are made concerning the effects of changes in intake temperature and pressure on the pre-ignition of different fuels.

A growing current concern is occasional gas-phase, autoignitive, pre-ignitions that can occur in turbo-charged engines, giving rise to very severe autoignition and knock. It is concluded from the evidence of engine pressure records and autoignition delay times of the mixtures that such pre-ignitions have not arisen from autoignition of the fuel, but of a mixture with a smaller autognition delay time than stoichiometric n-heptane–air. One possibility is that autoignition occurs at hot spots containing some lubricating oil. It is shown that such pre-ignitions, particularly with catalytic enhancement, could initiate a propagating flame, rather than autoignitive propagation.

In the later, much more severe autoignition arising after pre-ignition, autoignitive propagation velocities at a hot spot are estimated from computed values of the ignition delay times and assumed reactivity gradients in the fuel–air mixture at the hot spot. The severity of the associated pressure pulse is dependent upon the ratios
ξ
, of the acoustic speed to the localised autoignitive velocity, and
ε
, of the residence time of the acoustic wave in the hot spot to the short excitation time in which most of the chemical energy is released. The regime in which a localised detonation can be generated in the hot spot is defined by a peninsula on a plot of
ξ
against
ε
. A locus is plotted on this figure corresponding to the growing measured intensities of the engine knock as the pressure increases. This is based on computed autoignition delays and excitation times, for an appropriate surrogate fuel. These changes are characterised by
ξ
tending to unity and
ε
tending to ever-higher values, with increasingly intense, localised, developing detonations.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: At present, the development of direct injection spark-ignition (SI) engines focuses on downsizing, with the reduction in engine displacement and the use of turbo-charging to give better control of the air flow over the full power range, as a means of improving efficiency. Pre-ignition becomes more prevalent in such engines, creating a possible limiting factor to downsizing. It is akin to uncontrolled spark advance and, because of the already increased pressure from turbo-charging, it can lead to particularly severe and damaging autoignition and knock.1 It can be a rare event, with as many as 30,000 normal cycles between pre-ignitions.2

Problems with pre-ignition initially arose in the 1950s, following improvements in octane numbers (ONs) and increases in compression ratios. Pre-ignitions were shown to be initiated at hot combustion chamber deposits, spark plugs and valves.3 This earlier start to the combustion further increased the pressure and temperature of the unburned gas ahead of the advancing flame front, and the tendency of the end gases to autoignite. The increased pressure during the compression stroke could also lead to excessive negative work, loss of power and an increased rate of heat transfer to solid surfaces that might further intensify pre-ignition.4 This could cause a single-cylinder engine to stop, but with multi-cylinder engines, the other cylinders continued to operate. However, the high pressure and temperature developed by pre-ignition could cause the failure of the piston or the connecting rod, as shown in Figure 6.2 of Ricardo and Hempson.4

Downs and Pigneguy5 developed an engine-based technique to compare the influence of different fuels on surface pre-ignition, using a Ricardo E6 engine with a fixed compression ratio and spark advance, and a controlled electrically heated coil as a pre-igniter. The minimum electrical power to the pre-igniter that caused surface pre-ignition created a ranking order of the different fuels: a high power indicated a high pre-ignition rating (PR).6 In addition, the temperature of the coil was measured. The growing use of turbo-charging has focused attention on pre-ignition as a performance limiting factor.7,8 In methanol-fuelled engines, noble metal coatings on spark plug electrodes have been observed to promote surface pre-ignition,7 as has a calcium-based oil additive.9 A glow plug was used by Hamilton et al.8 to create surface hot spots at different temperatures to differentiate the propensity to surface pre-ignition and knock intensity between different fuel blends. With ethanol and E85 there was a general tendency for pre-ignition to increase with increases in compression ratio up to 15.8

When engine performance was becoming more limited by surface pre-ignition than by knock, it was found that pre-ignition correlated better with combustion chamber deposits than with ONs.10,11 Further work suggested the source of such pre-ignition to be mineral deposits on exhaust valves, usually coming from fuel and lubricant additives. The most harmful were barium and calcium phosphates, originating from detergent additives.12 Surfaces are covered by varying amounts of deposits, the properties of which depend on the fuel, lubricant and operating conditions.13

Pre-ignitions are sporadic, necessitating research data to be either stored in a large linear ring memory or through an appropriate event trigger.14 Present causes of pre-ignition have been attributed to surface ignition, residual gas distribution, hot particles in the residual gas mixing with the fresh charge, fuel decomposition incurred by boiling behaviour of individual components and charge heterogeneity.14 Surface pre-ignition and gas-phase autoignition were ruled out by Han et al.,15 and pre-ignition was attributed to diffusive combustion of mixture portions resulting from the previous cycle. Later, Dahnz et al.16 concluded, in their study of a turbo-charged engine, that the possibility of pre-ignitions at hot surfaces could be virtually excluded. They proposed a different mechanism for gas-phase pre-ignition, attributing it to lubricant oil droplets from the oil film on the cylinder liner, with a lower self-ignition temperature than the fuel.2
In summary, recent work on pre-ignition in turbo-charged engines, sometimes creating very intense knock, suggests pre-ignition is characterised by:

list-item.p: higher pressures and temperatures that spasmodically give rise to gas-phase pre-ignitions;
autoignitions at even higher pressures and temperatures that might cause very severe, damaging, knock;
injector sprays striking surrounding surfaces and stripping lubricating oil from them;
lubricating oil and fuel mixing with the main hot charge and autoigniting due to the lower ignition temperature;
residual gas or particles creating hot spots;
different pre-ignition rankings of different fuels.

sec.p: The paper first analyses pre-ignition at hot surfaces and the conditions necessary for the establishment of a propagating flame. This is followed by analysis of pre-ignition remote from surfaces. For this to occur, localised autoignition must occur at a suitable gas-phase ‘hot spot’ and initiate a propagating flame. For autoignitive pre-ignition, the autoignition delay time must be short enough, and the size of the hot spot must exceed the critical size for self-heating and be large enough to initiate a propagating flame. Early pre-ignition compresses the mixture to higher temperatures and pressures, at which autoignition and excitation delay times are significantly lower, and it is shown how these can cause ‘super-knock’.

sec.title: Theoretical approaches
sec.p: Historically, the necessary condition for ignition of a mixture was specified by the minimum energy necessary for ignition using an electric spark.17 However, this energy also comprised that transferred to the elec-trodes, electrical losses in the circuit and the energy generated in the shock wave, and was, clearly, not solely a function of the mixture. Furthermore, the energy in a spark discharge, with electron temperatures of about 20,000 K during the initial generation of a plasma, was well in excess of that required to sustain a spherical explosion flame of minimum size. The concept of the minimum ignition energy then shifted to that of a minimum critical size that must be attained by a hot kernel for a flame to propagate. The size would be of the order of the laminar flame thickness.17

Such a minimum ignition energy can be computed using detailed chemical kinetics and might be defined as the energy imparted to the mixture to initiate a spherical flame with equilibrated burned gas at the equilibrium temperature. If the imparted energy is insufficient in the initial induction period, the propagation speed of the kernel decreases and a flame cannot develop. As the energy is increased, eventually, extensive chain branching occurs and the flame develops, whilst being subjected initially to a high flame stretch rate.18 The minimum ignition energy and the associated critical size are key factors in determining whether pre-ignition might occur.

To avoid lengthy chemical kinetic and stretched flame computations, a relatively simple and convenient approach to the critical size for flame initiation at a hot surface will be adopted. This is based on the work of Zeldovich et al.19 and Longting He and Clavin.20 The critical radius, rf, of a hot spherical pocket of burned gas to initiate a propagating flame is given by

where

sec.title: Effects of different fuels
sec.p:
The dependence of

Values of

, m and p, for stoichiometric values of five contrasting fuels, hydrogen, ethanol, i-octane, a gasoline and methane, are listed in Table 1. The gasoline data are those measured for the gasoline by Tian et al.27 and Jerzembeck et al.28 Unlike the other four pure fuels, gasoline is a variable mixture of components, with consequent variable properties. Values of p were based on pressures between 0.1 and at least 1 MPa, and values of m on temperatures between 300 K and 360 K. Unfortunately, there are few data available for the higher operational values of T and P in engines, and data have had to be extrapolated. Of particular importance are the changes in the thickness of any potential flame during polytropic compression, and the effects of any increases in the temperature or pressure of the intake air.

caption.p: Pressure and temperature effects on burning velocities and flame thicknesses of different stoichiometric mixtures, n = 1.35 for q. See equations (2) and (3).

sec.p: If the gas is compressed polytropically with a polytropic index of n from initial conditions indicated by the suffix o, equation (2), when combined with the polytropic law, T/To = (P/Po)(n−1)/n, yields

in which q = [m(n− 1)/n] −p. Derived values of q with n = 1.35, are given in Table 1. With regard to the changing values of
δ
during compression, it can readily be shown that substituting the polytropic relationship into the last term in equation (3) yields

The exponent (−0.61 −q) is always numerically negative, and hence the potential flame thicknesses always decrease with increasing pressure. When, for a particular mixture, the potential flame thickness has decreased to approximately that of the thermal sheath around any appropriate hot surface, pre-ignition becomes possible. PRs, measured in engines, have been presented in comparative terms, normalised to values of 100 for an i-octane mixture by Ricardo and Hempson4 and Downs et al.5,6 The same datum will be used for the different mixtures, with equation (5) giving the ratios of the flame thickness of the different fuels, (fuel A) to that of i-octane (fuel B) as the pressure increases.

The pressure P is measured in atmospheres and Po is equal to 1 atm. In equation (5), the subscripts A and B for
δ
,
δ
o
and q refer to the two fuels, to give

Values of δA/δB, found in this way for the five selected fuels, are plotted against P in Figure 1. The potential flame thicknesses at the lower pressures would be too large for pre-ignition. As they approached values that might be comparable to the thickness of potential pre-igniting thermal sheaths at hot surfaces, the normalised thicknesses featured on the figure tended towards steady values. Relative to stoichiometric i-octane–air, the large thickness for methane makes it the most resistant to pre-ignition, while the significantly smaller thickness for hydrogen makes it the least resistant. The i-octane is more resistant than the gasoline, which is more resistant than the ethanol.

caption.p: Potential laminar flame thicknesses, normalised by those of i-octane, for different stoichiometric mixtures during polytropic compression.

sec.p: The experimental derivation of such comparative ratings has been the objective of several engine investigations,5,11,29 which have consistently shown i-octane to have a good resistance to pre-ignition. Downs and Theobald6 measured the minimum electrical power for a pre-igniter to cause pre-ignition of different fuels in a Ricardo E.6 single-cylinder engine. Fuels were rated according to the measured electrical power to cause pre-ignition: the higher the minimum electrical power for pre-ignition, the higher the PR. The i-octane was assigned a PR value of 100 and cyclohexane one of 0. When the thermal sheath around the pre-igniter attained a thickness comparable to rf, surface pre-ignition might be expected to occur. Of the pure hydrocarbons studied by Downs and Theobald,6 only the aromatics m-xylene and p-xylene had ratings higher than 100, whereas lightly catalytically cracked gasoline had a lower rating of 43.6.

Menrad et al.7 used the maximum possible spark advance before the onset of surface pre-ignition as a measure of resistance to pre-ignition. The i-octane proved to have the greatest resistance followed, in descending order, by the gasoline, ethanol and methanol. Ethanol and its blends certainly have higher pre-ignition tendencies than gasoline, which increase with compression ratio.8 The good resistance of methane to pre-ignition is well-attested as is, in contrast, the poor resistance of hydrogen. The latter is usually expressed by its low minimum ignition energy of 0.02 mJ for a stoichiometric mixture, which contrasts with a value of 0.3 mJ for stoichiometric methane.30 Such is the proneness of hydrogen engines to pre-ignition, for practical applications, the maximum value of the equivalence ratio is limited to about 0.6.30 The ranking order of normalised flame thickness in Figure 1 therefore corresponds well with the measured values of PR and other engine assessments.

If hydrogen is excluded, then for the common stoichiometric hydrocarbon–air mixtures, the differences in Le,
β
and ν in equation (1), at a given temperature and pressure, are unlikely to be very significant and rf should therefore be close to being inversely proportional to
u
ℓ
. The engine measurements by Downs and Theobald6 were made over a range of equivalence ratios, close to stoichiometric, where pre-ignitions were most likely, with the normal operating temperature of the surface at which ignition occurred ranging between 800 °C and 900 °C. The inlet air temperature was 60 °C and the compression ratio was 6. For a given fuel, the PR was a minimum when the mixture strength was around 10% richer than stoichiometric, where
u
ℓ
would be close to its maximum value. Hamilton et al.8 found that for given experimental conditions, pre-ignition was not possible outside a range of mixture strengths straddling stoichiometry. In so far as the minimum electrical power in the determination of the PR occurs at the minimum value of rf and the maximum value of
u
ℓ
, namely
u
ℓ max
, it is appropriate to plot values of PR against the reciprocal of
u
ℓ max
.

There are few measurements of
u
ℓ
over the ranges of temperature and pressure employed in the engine ratings. Consequently, the maximum values of
u
ℓ
at 0.304 MPa and 450 K were taken from the data bank of Figure 15 in Farrell et al.,31 and these are reproduced in Table 2. Values of PR are taken from Figure 9 of Ricardo and Hempson4 and, for ethanol, from Thring.32 These are plotted against the reciprocal of
u
ℓ max
in Figure 2. Clearly, there is a broad correlation between PR and
u
− 1
, which can provide an initial ranking of the propensity of fuels to pre-ignition, with equation (6) giving more detailed information.

caption.p: Pre-ignition rating (PR) plotted against 1/ulmax for different hydrocarbons; see Table 2. PR data from Downs and Theobald6 and ulmax data from Farrell et al.31

Maximum burning velocity uℓmax and pre-ignition rating, PR, for different hydrocarbon fuels: uℓmax is from Figure 15 of Farrell et al.,31 and is the maximum laminar burning velocity measured at a pressure of 0.304 MPa and a temperature of 450 K. PR is from Figure 4.9 of Ricardo and Hempson,4 and for ethanol, from Thring.32

sec.p:
It is to be expected that increasing exhaust gas recirculation, without any increase in intake temperature, would increase resistance to pre-ignition by reducing
u
ℓ
. However, this valuable method of ranking fuels, dominated by the effect of a thermal sheath around a fixed igniter, provides no information on the effect of different surfaces.

Values of research octane number (RON) and motor octane number (MON), also are given in Table 2, and the associated PR values are plotted against each of these in turn in Figures 3 and 4. In both cases, the correlation is poor. This confirms the findings in Downs and Theobald6 that, although the PR of all fuels was improved by the addition of lead, there was no general relationship between PR and ON. There is clear support for this type of surface pre-ignition being a flame initiation, rather than an autoignitive phenomenon.

caption.p: Pre-ignition rating (PR) versus research octane number (RON) for different hydrocarbons; see Table 2. Data from Farrell et al.31
Pre-ignition rating, PR, versus motor octane number (MON) for different hydrocarbons; see Table 2. Data from Farrell et al.31

When the exponent (3/2 − m)/ (0.61 + q) is positive, as is the case with i-octane, comparable flame thicknesses are only achieved at greater pressures as the intake heating increases. Surface pre-ignition is inhibited by the increased intake temperature. When the exponent is negative, as is the case with ethanol, comparable flame thicknesses are achieved at smaller pressures. Pre-ignition is now more likely as a result of the increased intake temperature. Ethanol has the greatest sensitivity for propensity to pre-ignition followed, in order, by methane, gasoline, hydrogen and i-octane.

The effects of changes in air intake temperature have not been investigated to the same extent as the effects of different fuels. Up to an inlet temperature ratio of 1.19, Downs and Theobald6 found no measurable effect on pre-ignition, whilst Menrad et al.7 found susceptibility to pre-ignition to decrease up to an inlet temperature ratio of 1.06. In both these studies, it is not clear what the fuels were. Figure 5 suggests that with a gasoline as the fuel, at small temperature ratios, any effect would be difficult to detect with any certainty. In view of the importance of the effects of higher intake temperatures resulting from turbochargers and exhaust gas recirculation, it would seem that further work is required in this area. The present calculations assumed a constant pressure. In practice, this might be increased when the intake temperature increases, in order to maintain power.7

When the exponent (q + p − 0.39)/(0.61 + q) is positive, as is the case with ethanol, comparable flame thicknesses are only achieved at greater pressures as the intake pressure increases. Surface pre-ignition is inhibited. When the exponent is negative, as in the case of i-octane, comparable flame thicknesses are achieved at smaller pressures, and pre-ignition is more likely. The i-octane has the greatest sensitivity for propensity to autoignition followed, in order, by hydrogen, gasoline, methane and ethanol. This trend is contrary to that exhibited for increases in intake temperature in Figure 5.

The studies in the sections on changes in air intake temperature and pressure are confined to their direct influences. However, increases in these also lead to hotter engine cycles and hotter potentially pre-igniting surfaces, which will also increase propensities to pre-ignitions. As in the case of studies of the influence of air intake temperature, the authors are unaware of any comprehensive studies of the influence of intake pressure for different fuels. The importance of initiating such studies is clear.

sec.title: Engine pressure records and pre-ignition in engines
sec.p: Figures 7 and 8 show pressure records, kindly provided by Dr Manz of VW and Dr Rothenberger of GM Powertrain. These were measured in their laboratories on two different turbo-charged engines, each with an intake pressure of 0.2 MPa. Engine 1 ran at 1750 r/min, and Figure 7 shows a normal, non-knocking, cycle, N1, with the spark at 7 crank angle degrees after top dead centre (CAD ATDC) and another, S1, which pre-ignites, creating ‘super-knock’, with a knock intensity (KI) defined as the peak-to-peak pressure fluctuation, of over 13 MPa. Values of RON/MON were 98/89. Engine 2 ran with fuels of RON/MON of 95/85, at 2000 r/min and, in Figure 8, N2 is a normal cycle, in which marginal knock might occur, with the spark at 2.3 CAD before top dead centre (BTDC), here without pre-ignition. The cycle K2 is one with fairly heavy knock, KI ∼ 2.4 MPa, with pre-ignition at 6.0 CAD BTDC, while the cycle S2 pre-ignites at 19.0 CAD BTDC, creating ‘super-knock’, KI ∼ 14.5 MPa. The pre-ignitions in the ‘super-knock’ cycles S1 and S2, respectively, are estimated to have occurred at pressures and temperatures of about 2.9 MPa and 638 K1 and at about 3.7 MPa and 682 K.14 The conditions at the initiation of knock are given in Table 3.

caption.p: Source: reproduced with permission from VW, 2009.
Source: reproduced with permission from GM Powertrain, 2009.
Conditions at the initiation of knock shown in Figures 7 and 8.

sec.p: In contrast to earlier studies, modern engines, in which pre-ignition has again become a concern, have direct injection of the fuel, combined with significantly higher in-cylinder pressures as a result of turbo-charging. Empirical evidence suggests that in such engines, pre-ignition is unlikely to be initiated at internal surfaces, but in the body of the charge.2,14,16 The work by Zadeh et al.2 and Dahnz et al.16 also suggests that fuel droplets from the injecting spray impinge on the cylinder wall and mix with the lubricating oil film, changing its surface tension and viscosity. This oil–fuel mixture could collect in the crevice volume of the top land of the piston, with the possibility of droplets of the mixture being entrained in the main mixture in the cylinder.

Dahnz et al.16 proposed such a mechanism after observing gas-phase autoignitive pre-ignitions, distributed in space at small, well-defined ignition kernels. Flames propagated from these at the relatively low speeds normally associated with spark ignition. It will be shown in the next section that autoignition of the main fuel–air mixture is unlikely, and in the following section that the autoigniting hot spot must be somewhat more reactive than stoichiometric heptane–air.

sec.title: Autoignition delay times of different fuels
sec.p:
Autoignitions of primary reference fuels (PRFs) are first briefly considered, in terms of how autoignition delay times,
τ
i
, vary with T and P. Figure 9 shows a plot of values of
τ
i
against 1000/T for PRFs with ONs ranging from 0 to 100, for stoichiometric mixtures with air at 4 MPa, taken from Fieweger et al.33 For these PRFs,
τ
i
is inversely proportional to pressure, varying approximately as
p
− 1 . 7
.34 For the pre-ignition pressures and temperatures of both the ‘super-knock’ cycles, S1 and S2, of the previous section, Figure 9 suggests a value of
τ
i
in the region of 10 ms, or higher, for a 95 ON PRF. This would be too high for general autoignition of the charge. Similarly, the values of
τ
i
for the surrogate mixture that simulates the actual engine fuel, see the section on second autoignition, would also be too high for autoignition at these engine conditions. Clearly, the engines were not operating in a regime in which autoignition of the main fuel–air mixture was to be expected, yet autoignitive pre-ignition was indeed observed to occur. Hence, another explanation of the autoignition must be sought.

caption.p: Autoignition delay times, τi, for stoichiometric PRFs from Fieweger et al.33 at 4 MPa.

sec.p: The authors are unaware of any data on the autoignition delay times of lubricating oil–air mixtures. Because of the variety of lubricating oil additives, it is probable that there could be a wide range of delay times. However, the long-chain molecules of the oils are probably inherently associated with shorter autoignition delay times. In lieu of definitive data for lubricating oils, data for long-chain n-heptane will be used to provide some tentative guidance about autoignitive pre-ignition. To cover the important lower temperature range for n-heptane, the computed autoignition data of Peters et al.35 are employed.

However, the values of
τ
i
in Peters et al.35 would seem to be still rather high for autoignition to occur at the measured pre-ignition pressures and estimated temperatures. The value would be higher than 10 ms at the lower pressure of 2.9 MPa, and about 4 ms at the higher pressure of 3.7 MPa for the autoignitive pre-ignitions observed in the two super-knock cycles, S1 and S2, respectively. The corresponding values of
τ
i
for a lubricating oil would probably be smaller. Whatever the detailed autoignitive mechanism for pre-ignition might be, it was observed to seed a normal propagating flame. Overall, three conditions have emerged as necessary for this type of pre-ignition:

list-item.p:
the size of the hot spot must not be less than the critical radius for autoignition,
r
c
;
for the autoignited hot spot to initiate a flame, its radius must not be less than the critical radius for flame propagation, rf, in equation (1).

sec.p: These possibilities are examined through a more detailed reference to autoignition delay times and the determination of rc and rf. Conditions (a) and (b) are discussed sequentially in the next two sections.

sec.title: Duration of delay times and critical size for autoignition
sec.p:
With regard to condition (a),
τ
i
being small enough, even at the higher pressure condition of 3.7 MPa and 682 K, as already mentioned,
τ
i
is rather too high. With regard to condition (b), the critical radius for gas-phase autoignition,
r
c
, is the smallest radius at which the heat lost by conduction from the hot spot is balanced by the chemical heat release, to sustain a steady state. Hot spots with a radius less than this critical value will decay; those with a greater radius will explode. The more reactive the hot spot, the smaller the critical radius. For a spherically symmetric pre-ignition centre, a simplified quasi-steady-state energy equation with an Arrhenius reaction rate of factor A and activation energy E is36
in which k is the thermal conductivity, T the temperature, r the radius and Q the mass of fuel per unit volume multiplied by the enthalpy of reaction.

Thermal explosion theory presents solutions for the critical radius,
r
c
, in terms of the dimensionless critical Frank–Kamenetskii parameter,
δ
c
. Solution of equation (21) is discussed by Takeno,37 who also gives values of
δ
c
as a function of
E
n
= (E/RTa), where Ta is the ambient temperature. Values of
r
c
are given by

Although
δ
c
decreases with
E
n
, the rapid decrease in
E
n
exp
( −
E
n
)
in equation (22) is much more significant, and low values of
r
c
occur at low values of
E
n
. At temperatures below about 700 K, a stoichiometric n-heptane–air mixture has a value of E/R of 15,107 K.35 With
T
a
= 682 K, estimated as a mean value for the gas-phase autoignitive pre-ignition at the higher pressure of 3.7 MPa,
E
n
= 22.15 and
δ
c
= 3.43 for a sphere. Measured values of A derived from autoignition heat release rates in engines were approximately 2 × 109 s−1.38 With a mass fraction of n-heptane and a mixture density of 13.28 kg/m3, Q becomes 36.64 MJ/m3. Substitution of these different values in equation (22) gives a value of
r
c
= 0.54 mm. This could be relatively large and, with a value of
τ
i
= 4 ms, autoignition would be unlikely.

However, the data in Peters et al.35 show that if the mixture temperature were to be above about 700 K, not only
τ
i
, but also E/R, would decrease. As a result at, say, 763 K, well above the apparent temperature of 682 K, but still at a pressure of 3.7 MPa,
τ
i
becomes 1 ms and, on that count, gas-phase autoignition would become more probable. In addition, E/R would decrease to 11,400 K and
E
n
to 14.9. With
δ
c
= 3.52 and Q = 32.75 MJ/m3,
r
c
is reduced to 5.6 µm, a minimum size that can readily be exceeded by a hot spot. Autoignition is now much more probable and, after it, the volume of the original hot spot would increase about seven fold, giving a minimal radius of 11 µm.

sec.title: Critical hot spot size for flame initiation
sec.p:
With regards to condition (c), for a propagating flame to be initiated in the main mixture after gas-phase autoignition, the size of the hot spot must exceed the critical radius, rf, of a hot pocket of burned gas, given by equation (1). Any potential flame with a value of rf that is less than the radius of the hot spot would be able to propagate. It is sufficient to approximate the mixture to stoichiometric i-octane–air, for which values of
u
ℓ
and
β
are given at up to 1.0 MPa and 450 K in Bradley et al.25 It is also sufficiently accurate to extrapolate these values to 3.7 MPa and 763 K using the given expression and data.25 These yield
u
ℓ
= 0.37 m/s and
β
=7. With Le = 0.95 and
ν
= 1.8 × 10−6 m2/s,21 from equation (1) rf = 4.1 µm. The minimal radius of the autoignited volume of hot gas of 11 µm, calculated in the previous section is 2.7 times greater than this, and hence it is possible for a flame to propagate from the hot spot, completing the gas-phase pre-ignition mechanism. At its inception, because of the small size of the autoignited hot spot, the flame would be laminar, but would become turbulent as it propagated and its surface became wrinkled due to the increasing scales of the turbulence. Because of the larger values of
τ
i
and
∂
τ i
/
∂ T
outside the hot spot, normal flame propagation would dominate over autoignitive propagation (see the section on the violence of ‘super-knock’).

The attainment of all the conditions for an autoignitive gas-phase pre-ignition that creates a normal flame at 3.7 MPa is only possible for a stoichiometric n-heptane mixture hot spot, embedded in a stoichiometric i-octane main mixture, by assuming a temperature of 763 K, rather higher than the mean value of 682 K. Autoignition regimes were computed by Dahnz et al.16 for n-heptane droplets in stoichiometric i-octane–air, a surrogate for gasoline, at 4 MPa. It was found that homogeneous autoignition was only possible at temperatures above 780 K.

There are a number of ways in which this autoignitive ‘shortfall’ might be provided, in addition to lubricating oil with a lower
τ
i
. It is established that catalytic reactions can enhance pre-ignitions at surfaces, with and without deposits.6,7,9 It is possible that catalysis is also important for fuel–oil droplet reactions at hot spots. In Zadeh et al.,2 the use of an oil with few additives, particularly those based on calcium and barium, seemed to eradicate previous sporadic gas-phase pre-ignitions. Other possible enhancers of autoignition are severe heterogeneity of the charge, and small hot particles that have been transferred with hot gases from the previous cycle.39 Clearly, further work is required to develop detailed mechanisms for autoignitive pre-ignitions.

Although manifestations of super-knock are dramatic, the key to their occurrence lies in this earlier gas-phase autoignitive pre-ignition. Dahnz and Spicher40 showed that, although such pre-ignitions occurred with a frequency of less than 4 in 10,000 cycles, they were concentrated in bursts of no more than about four or five cycles, with alternating regular burn and pre-igniting cycles.

A possible explanation of this regular periodicity is that, following pre-ignition, the very high pressures of super-knock occur much earlier in the cycle. As a result, at the end of the expansion stroke, the burned gas would be at a lower temperature than with normal combustion. The burned gas remaining in the cylinder for the next cycle would consequently lower the mean temperature in that cycle, inhibiting autoignitive pre-ignition. At the end of the expansion stroke in this normal cycle, the burned gas would be at a higher temperature, possibly sufficient for the residual gas to enhance pre-ignition in the next cycle. Efficient engine combustion on the fringe of super-knock can be nullified by insufficiently understood rare cyclic excursions into autoignitive pre-ignitions, as a result of the sensitivity of marginal autoignition to comparatively small in-cylinder changes.

sec.title: The second autoignition: autoignitive initiation of ‘super-knock’
sec.p:
This section deals with the consequences of the earlier gas-phase, autoignitive pre-ignition, namely a second much more violent gas-phase autognition arising at another ‘hotter’ spot in the end gas. Hot spots are characterised by gradients of reactivity, manifest as gradients of autoignition delay time. These can induce autoignitive propagation velocities, the control of which is important in autoignitive engines. Here, for illustrative purposes, it is assumed that reactivity gradients are due entirely to gradients of temperature and not of composition. The reaction front then propagates at a velocity relative to the unburned gas of
u
a
, given by

If it is assumed that
τ
i
can be expressed locally at constant pressure in Arrhenius form by

where
A ′
is a numerical constant, then from equations (23) and (24)

If
∂ T
/
∂ r
is assumed to be −1 K/mm, this expression yields values for
u
a
of 3 and 51 m/s within the hot spot for the low- and high-pressure pre-ignition conditions for n-heptane, respectively, discussed in the previous section.

In contrast, at the onset of the ‘super-knock’ in Figures 7 and 8, the pressures are 13.3 MPa and 12.8 MPa for cycles S1 and S2, with estimated temperatures of 918 K and 926 K, respectively. It was assumed that this second gas-phase autoignition was initiated where a knee first appeared in the pressure curve, indicative of a sudden change in the heat release rate. In this case, the associated autoignition is not occurring in something akin to a rare heptane–air fragment, but at a hot spot in the main fuel–air mixture, somewhere in the end gas. We first assume that the mixture is a PRF stoichiometric mixture of 95 ON, with values of
τ
i
from Figure 9, with due allowance for the different pressures. When this allowance is made at 13 MPa and 920 K,
τ
i
is 0.15 ms and with
∂ T
/
∂ r
= −1 K/mm,
u
a
from equation (23) attains the higher value of 608 m/s. Autoignition can clearly occur within the available time. With regard to the critical size of a hot spot, the value of AQ is greater than 1011 MW/m3, and E/R is less than 10,000 K,34 giving a hot spot critical radius of about 3 µm,36 which can readily be exceeded by a hot spot.

The origin of knock lies in the pressure waves generated by the rapid rate of change of the rate of volume generation,
d V
/
d t
, at the hot spot reaction front. At a sufficient distance, d, from the autoigniting hot spot, the pressure pulse approximates that from a monopole sound source. Simple acoustic theory gives the associated instantaneous sound pressure,
p ( t )
, above the ambient at time t as41

where
t
a
is the time for the sound wave to propagate the distance d from the source to its measurement point, through a non-reacting gas of density
ρ
.

If r is the hot spot radius, 4πr2 is the area of the reaction front propagating relative to the unburned gas at a velocity
u
a
, then the volumetric rate of consumption of unburned gas volume is
4 π
r
2
u
a
. The corresponding volumetric rate of production of burned gas is greater in the ratio of unburned to burned densities, σ, hence

The overpressure above the ambient generated by the propagation of the reaction front through the hot spot, is found by differentiating equation (27) with respect to t and substituting in equation (26). Ultimately, this leads to a dimensionless expression for the overpressure42

in which
ξ =
a /
u a
, the acoustic speed
a =
γ p
/ ρ
,
γ
is the ratio of specific heats and
t
¯
=
t /
t
r o
, where
t
ro
=
r o
/ a
, the time for an acoustic wave to traverse the original hot spot radius.

Equation (28) is only valid in the absence of shock waves and detonations and for these conditions, the final term in
d
ξ
− 1
/
d
t ¯
can be relatively small. The maximum pressure will occur at the maximum radius of the reacting hot spot. The multiplying terms for
ξ
− 2
in the dominant first term are often of order unity in engines, so
p
( t )
max
/ p
is of order
ξ
− 2
. The smaller the value of
ξ
, the greater the strength of the pressure pulses. Under the observed conditions at the initiation of the ‘super-knock’, a = 576 m/s, for
∂ T
/
∂ r
= −1 K/mm,
ξ
= 576/608 = 0.95, and
p
( t )
max
/ p
is of order unity, for a PRF of 95 ON. This is approximately in accord with the pressure records in Figures 7 and 8, where the knock intensity is of the same order as the mean pressure.

However, for non-PRF mixtures, the values of
τ
i
for the PRF with the same ON are insufficiently accurate at high pressure. This is because of a general tendency for
τ
i
values of PRF mixtures to decrease more as the pressure increases than those of non-PRF mixtures with the same ON.34 This is the basis of the decrease with increasing pressure of a linear weighting factor, K, to the point where it becomes negative, in the relationship for the octane index (OI)43

As a result of the higher values of
τ
i
for the non-PRF fuels employed in engines 1 and 2, the OIs were 107 and 105, higher than their RON values. To obtain values of
τ
i
commensurate with the non-PRFs, values of
τ
i
were computed for a surrogate fuel. This comprised 62% i-octane, 29% toluene and 9% n-heptane, by volume. The chemical kinetic computations for the autoignition of this surrogate were reported by Andrae et al.44 The computed value of
τ
i
at the initiation of super-knock was 0.3 ms, about twice the value for the 95 ON PRF, with an associated approximate doubling of
ξ
. Values of
τ
i
for the surrogate fuel at different temperatures and pressures of 4, 8 and 12 MPa are shown in Figure 10.

caption.p:
Ignition delay times,
τ
i
, for stoichiometric mixtures of surrogate fuel.44

sec.p:
Where it is clear from the values of
τ
i
that autoignition will occur, in order to estimate its violence, it is necessary to know the pressure and temperature at its onset. This instant is that at which the Livengood–Wu integral attains a value of unity during the time
t ′
.45 The integral is defined by

Values of the autoignition delay time,
τ
i
( T , P )
, were found using the detailed chemical kinetics for the surrogate fuel, for the changing conditions during the compression, and I was evaluated from equation (30). Further details are given in Kalghatgi et al.1Figure 11 shows the integral, I, plotted against CAD for the three knocking cycles. For Cycles S1, S2 and K2, I reaches unity at 2.9 CAD ATDC, 1.6 CAD BTDC and 22.4 CAD ATDC, respectively, in remarkably close agreement with the observed onset of autoignition in both engines, recorded in Figures 7 and 8 at 3.0 CAD ATDC, 2.0 CAD BTDC and 20.0 CAD ATDC.

caption.p: Livengood–Wu integral for cycles S1, S2 and K2.

sec.title: The violence of ‘super-knock’
sec.p:
Equation (28) is only valid in the absence of shock waves and detonations. The situation is quite different when there are large changes in density at the pressure front, and when chemical energy can be fed into the developing strong pressure wave at a hot spot. Under these conditions, the principal energy release occurs during an excitation time,
τ
e
, which is orders of magnitude less than
τ
i
. The rapidity of this release influences the strength of the pressure pulse.46 A measure of this energy input to the pressure pulse is the residence time of the acoustic wave within the hot spot,
t
ro
divided by
τ
e
, and indicated by
ε
. This is the number of excitation times passing into the pressure pulse during its time in the hot spot, so that
ε
=
(
r o
/ a
)
/
τ e
.

When the autoignition front moves into the unburned mixture at approximately the acoustic speed, a, the front of the pressure wave generated by the rate of heat release can couple with the autoignition reaction front. The fronts are mutually reinforced to create a damaging pressure spike propagating at high velocity within the hot spot in a developing detonation.47 Clearly with this degree of resonance between the chemical and acoustic waves, when
u
a
= a
, then
ξ =
a /
u a
, is unity.

The development of a detonation does not depend solely upon this resonance, but also upon
ε
. Because of the complexity of this coupling, a full understanding of a developing detonation requires a direct numerical simulation of the emerging front. Such simulations were made by Bradley et al.48 and Gu et al.49 with CO/H2–air mixtures under different conditions. These fuels were selected because the associated reaction kinetics were relatively well understood. It was found that the results of the computations could be usefully generalised by plotting regime boundary values of
ξ
against
ε
, as in Figure 12. Importantly, this shows a peninsula, with an upper limit
ξ
u
and a lower limit
ξ
l
, within which, detonations can begin to develop within the hot spot. Outside the peninsula are regimes of supersonic, P, and subsonic, B, autoignitive propagation.

caption.p: Conditions for the occurrence of developing detonations in terms of ξ and ε. Supersonic and subsonic autoignitive deflagrations occur in the regions marked P and B, respectively. Data from Bradley et al.48 extended.

sec.p:
With regards to the values of these two dimensionless groups, those of
τ
i
,
τ
e
and other parameters computed for the surrogate fuel44 at the onset of knock are given in Table 4. Very small time increments were necessary to compute
τ
e
, and these values for the surrogate fuel at different temperatures and pressures of 4, 8 and 12 MPa are shown in Figure 13. As in Lutz et al.,46
τ
i
varies significantly with T, and relatively less with P(Figure 10), whereas
τ
e
is a rather stronger function of P than of T(Figure 13).

caption.p: Excitation time, τe, for a stoichiometric mixture of surrogate fuel.49

Estimated parameters for the surrogate fuel44 in the four cycles considered in Figures 7 and 8:
r
o
= 5 mm and
∂ T
/ ∂ r
= −2 K/mm.

sec.p:
The gradient of autoignitive reactivity,
∂ T
/
∂ r
in the present case was, not unusually, unknown in the various engine tests. Unfortunately it has, so far, proved impossible to achieve the necessary spatial resolution, or accuracy in temperature measurements, to measure these gradients with sufficient accuracy. Guidance concerning the sensitivity to such gradients was obtained from the direct numerical simulation studies in Bradley et al. and Gu et al.48–50 and very limited experimental data, However, bearing in mind the clearance height at top centre, the possible integral length scale of turbulence and the general effectiveness of temperature gradients in promoting knock, values of
r
o
= 5 mm and
∂ T
/
∂ r
= −2 K/mm were assumed for knock initiation. These values were used to evaluate
ξ
and
ε
, which are also given in Table 4. It is possible to trace the presently observed transition from a normal cycle to one with ‘super-knock’ on Figure 12, and this is done by following the N2, K2, S curve. N2 represents normal running with engine 2, K2 fairly heavy knock with engine 2 and S represents the ‘super-knock’ conditions of cycles S1 and S2 with engines 1 and 2. The last cycle, E, on Table 4 and Figure 12, is an extrapolation of the S1/S2 conditions to a higher pressure of 15 MPa for the initiation of knock which, although not observed in the present experiments, is a possibility.

At the critical condition,
u
a
= a
, from equation (23), the critical temperature gradient for this condition is
From equations (23) and (31)

The increase in pressure to 15 MPa decreases
τ
e
and
(
a ∂
τ i
/
∂ T
)
, with resulting increases in ϵ and
(
∂ T
/
∂ r
)
c
, and, because of the latter, a resulting decrease in
ξ
. These extrapolated values are given in Table 4 and on the associated ‘super-knock’ locus, from S to E, in Figure 12. As this locus moves to higher values of ϵ and lower values of
ξ
, the severity of the knock increases. In the numerical simulations of Bradley et al.,48 the pressure ratio,
p
¯
, at the detonation front was found to increase as
d
p ¯
/
d ε
= 0.16. The greater propensity to intense detonations for values of
ξ
between 1 and 4 is indicated by the extended toe of the detonation peninsula at the lower values of ϵ in Figure 12.

In general, the developing detonation does not propagate outside the hot spot. In the direct numerical simulations in Bradley et al.,50 only with ϵ = 85 at a low value of
ξ
was the mixture reactive enough for the detonation to continue to propagate into the region of zero reactivity gradient outside the hot spot, albeit at higher temperatures than those in the present study. In sharp contrast, the condition of the charge within which the more benign autoignitive pre-ignition occurs, is one of high
ξ
and low ϵ, in which normal flame propagation would probably dominate over autoignitive propagation. This would be represented on Figure 12 by the bold locus being extended upwards from N2 to high values of
ξ
, at which a is significantly greater than
u
a
or the burning velocity of a normal flame, and towards lower values of ϵ. Clearly, loci of values of
ξ
, plotted against those for
ε
, are valuable in tracing the progressive transitions through the regimes of normal flame propagation, autoignitive propagation, no knock, benign knock, ‘normal’ knock, to ‘super-knock’. Although the present locus rests upon assumed values of
r
o
and
∂ T
/
∂ r
, it gives an indication of the factors leading to knock of mounting severity.

Continuation of the propagation of the detonation from a hot spot into the main mixture, were it to occur, would be very damaging. Almost equally damaging would be the strongly developing detonations within a multitude of hot spots. As the number of hot spots increases, so do the interactions between adjacent ones. Pan and Sheppard51 have shown experimentally that as autoignition fronts from adjacent hot spots propagate towards each other, the pressure fronts ahead of them increase the temperature and pressure of the reactants, leading to violent reactions and the generation of outwardly propagating shock waves. When the hot spots have developing detonations as strong as those in the ‘super-knock’ regime, this effect will be aggravated. The coupling of reaction fronts and shock waves can create further developing detonations, contributing to ‘super-knock’.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
Two types of pre-ignition have been analysed: one originating at a solid surface, the other in the gas phase. For the first, past experimental engine studies have involved the creation of a thermal boundary layer in the mixture around an electrically heated igniter. Surface pre-ignition occurred when the heating was sufficient to create a thickness of the boundary layer comparable to that of a propagating laminar flame in the mixture. This concept has been employed in the present work to predict the relative tendencies of different fuel mixtures to pre-ignite, and the effect on pre-ignition of changing the temperature of the intake air. The minimum electrical power for pre-ignition yielded the PR of the mixture. With a flame thickness,
δ , =
ν /
u ℓ
and with
ν
having very similar values for most near-stoichiometric hydrocarbon–air mixtures, the measured values of PR over a wide range of hydrocarbon fuels in Farrell et al.31 correlated well with
u
ℓ max
− 1
. Plots of PR against RON and MON re-confirmed there was little correlation with these parameters, suggesting that pre-ignition at a hot surface is caused by the initiation of flame propagation, rather than by autoignition.

In contrast, gas-phase autoignition has been postulated as the dominant mode of pre-ignition in direct injection, turbo-charged engines. Reference to
τ
i
data, for the pressures and temperature at which autoignitive pre-ignition was observed, show this could not be attributed to the main fuel–air mixture. One explanation of this infrequent phenomenon is autoignitive pre-ignition of the long-chain lubricating oil. However, to satisfy ignition delay time and critical initiating flame size requirements, the oil would have to be somewhat more autoignitively reactive than n-heptane. It is also possible that small particles and catalysis could enhance this process. Experimental data of the autoignition delay times of lubricating oils are required. Autoignitive pre-ignition has not been fully explained and it is, not surprisingly, a rare event. However, all else remaining unchanged, reducing the laminar burning velocity, for example, through the use of cooled exhaust gas recirculation, should reduce the likelihood of pre-ignition.

Computed values of
τ
i
, for the surrogate fuel, in the Livengood–Wu integral are able to predict the onset of the autoignition that led to knock of increasing severity in engine tests. An assumed gradient of reactivity, in this case dT/dr, at a hot spot, along with computed values of
τ
i
( T , P )
, enabled values of
ξ
to be found at different instants in the end gas. Prior to any development of a localised detonation, the over-pressure generated by autoignition at a hot spot is proportional to the hot spot radius and
ξ
−2. An assumed hot spot radius and computed values of
τ
e
( T , P )
for the surrogate enabled ϵ, a measure of the energy feeding into a shock front, to be found. As
ξ
decreases towards unity and ϵ increases, localised detonations develop with over-pressures that became more severe (‘super-knock’).

It has been shown how a locus of these changes on a plot of
ξ
against ϵ traces successive transitions through regimes of no knock, benign knock, ‘normal’ knock, to ‘super-knock’. The later stages are manifest in turbo-charged engines as occasional ‘super-knock’ at high pressure, following a pre-ignition that is akin to excessive spark advance. The observed increasing knock is commensurate with the locus of decreasing
ξ
, plotted against increasing
ε
for the end gas. Although the direct propagation of detonation outside a hot spot is unlikely, almost equally damaging would be the strongly developing detonations within a multitude of hot spots. However, the key to super-knock lies in the very occasional autoignitive pre-ignition that creates a normal propagating flame, rather than knock. This regime depends upon in-cylinder conditions, which include lubrication.
